4.title: Case Study 4: Flawed vs Corrected Time-of-Day Weekly Sales Visualization
4.subtitle: Design ethics
4.description: Both charts show the same kebab-sales dataset. The first collapses seven days into averages and breaks encoding rules; the second keeps all 42 rows visible with a clean mapping.

flawed.label: Flawed chart
flawed.title: Misleading weekly donut
flawed.caption: Looks like a weekly distribution of kebab sales by city and time, but it collapses seven days into six slices and hides the city encoding in tiny labels.
flawed.chartTitle: Weekly kebab sales distribution (time × city, flawed)
flawed.chartDescription: Seven concentric rings (one per day) squeeze city × time-of-day totals into decorative slices. Warm colors still encode only time, while the legend pretends they stand for cities.

reasons.axis: Seven concentric rings imply a third dimension, but no scale or markings tell you which ring corresponds to which day.
reasons.colors: All slices share the same warm hues per time of day, so two cities become impossible to separate visually.
reasons.legend: Legend labels pretend the colors encode cities (plus an average) even though the palette actually encodes time.
reasons.order: Rings stack inner → outer without any labels for days, so the weekly progression is hidden behind decoration.
reasons.aggregation: Each slice shows a daily total but the donut squeezes six metrics into a single angle, so city and day values blur together.
reasons.mapping: Angles encode city × time, rings secretly encode days, and the legend claims something else—the visual channels contradict the data structure.

fixed.label: Fixed chart
fixed.title: Truthful panel lines
fixed.caption: Same data with honest scaling, distinct colors, and a calm layout. Every single row stays visible in one stacked SVG.
fixed.chartTitle: Daily kebab sales by city and time of day
fixed.chartDescription: Single SVG with three horizontal panels (Morning, Midday, Evening). Each panel has two lines (Berlin, Köln) over seven days, shared x-scale, independent y-scales.

reasons.baseline: Each panel keeps its own y-axis and grid, so peaks stay readable no matter the band.
reasons.palette: Lines reuse the same high-contrast viridis colors whether they encode cities or times of day.
reasons.legend: Legend copy matches the active encoding and updates automatically with the toggle.
reasons.structure: Toggle flips between time-stacked and city-stacked panels without changing data or scales.
reasons.fullData: All 42 daily values (2 cities × 3 times × 7 days) remain visible—only the grouping changes.
reasons.mapping: Shared day axis, independent y-scales, dots for each day, and no hidden aggregation tricks.

5.title: Case Study 5: Dumbbell + Bubble City Comparison
5.subtitle: Dual encoding for customers, revenue, and menu types
5.description: Toggle between a menu-colored dumbbell and a bubble scatterplot to compare daily customers, revenue, and the number of shops per German city.

legend.customers: Left dots = customers per day (color follows menu type)

dumbbell.label: Shared-axis dumbbell
dumbbell.title: Customers vs revenue per city
dumbbell.description: Neutral connectors share one axis for customers and revenue; dots inherit menu colors and line weight scales with shop counts.
dumbbell.chartTitle: Daily customers vs revenue per city (dumbbell)
dumbbell.chartDescription: Each city uses menu color for the customer dot, an accent revenue dot, and a neutral connector. Shop counts print directly on the line.

notes.channels: Line length compares customers to revenue while stroke width and dot radius scale with the number of shops.
notes.labels: Inline labels print exact shop totals midway along each connector.
notes.shops: Menu-colored customer dots reveal which flavor drives traffic before the revenue comparison.

scatter.label: Bubble scatterplot
scatter.title: Bubble map of kebab demand
scatter.description: Bubbles sit on a customers × revenue grid with color for menu type, radius for shop count, and labels for both the city name and shop total.
scatter.chartDescription: Menu colors follow the legend, bubble radius tracks shop counts, the total sits inside each bubble, and the city label hugs the edge.

notes.quadrants: Gridlines highlight which cities are customer-heavy versus revenue-heavy.
notes.legend: The legend mirrors the Veggie/Hähnchen/Kalb palette so editors can reorder hues centrally.
notes.annotation: Each bubble prints the shop count inside and the full city label outside for quick scanning.

6.title: Case Study 6: Parallel Coordinates on Air Quality Stations
6.subtitle: Feinstaub focus across five pollutants.
6.description: Compare fine dust against four other pollutants across German monitoring stations in a normalized parallel coordinates plot.
6.summary: Parallel coordinates view of five pollutant scores per station with hover focus.

chart.title: Air quality metrics per station
chart.description: Parallel coordinates plot with one axis per pollutant and color-coded networks.
chart.note: Scores are normalized within this sample (0 = lowest, 10 = highest) so relative differences stay visible.

starPlot.title: Star plot per station
starPlot.description: Each station becomes a five-point star; one spoke per pollutant, colored by network.
starPlot.note: Best for a handful of stations—overplotting rises quickly as stars overlap.

highlights.normalized: All pollutants are normalized to 0–10 so every axis is comparable at a glance.
highlights.fineDust: The Feinstaub axis comes first to anchor the brief’s focus on particulate matter.
highlights.hover: Hover isolates one station path, reveals exact values, and gently fades the rest.

comparison.question: Können die Daten aller Messstationen abgelesen werden? Was gibt es beim Visualisierungsdesign zu beachten?

points.coverage: Parallel coordinates expose every station and pollutant at once; the star plot stays readable only with few stations before spokes overlap.
points.focus: Both views need hover focus; parallels dim the other lines cleanly, while the star plot benefits from highlighting one polygon and its labels.
points.design: Keep the metric order identical, reuse network colors, and if more stations arrive either filter or facet the star plot to avoid clutter.
